comments.body: I think the convention is no spaces in slices, I.e. after the colon.

Oh wow, that is confusing. I had to read like 5 times to see it, but
they're not slices, they're dict key/values.
On Nov 7, 2015 8:37 AM, "Jaime" notifications@github.com wrote:

> In numpy/core/tests/test_item_selection.py
> https://github.com/numpy/numpy/pull/6649#discussion_r44214162:
> 
> > @@ -18,10 +18,9 @@ def test_simple(self):
> >          index_arrays = [np.empty(0, dtype=np.intp),
> >                          np.empty(tuple(), dtype=np.intp),
> >                          np.empty((1, 1), dtype=np.intp)]
> > -        real_indices = {}
> > -        real_indices['raise'] = {-1:1, 4:IndexError}
> > -        real_indices['wrap'] = {-1:1, 4:0}
> > -        real_indices['clip'] = {-1:0, 4:1}
> > -        real_indices = {'raise': {-1: 1, 4: IndexError},
> 
> I think the convention is no spaces in slices, I.e. after the colon.
> 
> â€”
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/numpy/numpy/pull/6649/files#r44214162.
Is it fine then? Should it be merged?
Indeed they are, definitely no change needed...

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +19,23 @@                        np.empty(tuple(), dtype=np.intp),
                        np.empty((1, 1), dtype=np.intp)]
        real_indices = {'raise': {-1: 1, 4: IndexError},
                        'wrap': {-1: 1, 4: 0},
                        'clip': {-1: 0, 4: 1}}
